news.summary: Wall Street analysts are becoming increasingly bearish on Tesla (NASDAQ: TSLA).  Following the car maker's first-quarter deliveries announcement, Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives called the report a "disaster" and said CEO Elon Musk needs to "get his act together."  Wells Fargo analyst Colin Langan, meanwhile, has been far more critical of the stock, with an "underweight" rating and $130 price target on it.

Tesla (NASDAQ: TSLA) stock ended 2024 with a gain of 63%, partly because of President Donald Trump's November U.S. election win.  Investors speculated that a looser regulatory environment -- and CEO Elon Musk's closeness with Trump and his inner circle -- could pave the way for Tesla to bring its autonomous driving and humanoid robotics platforms to market more quickly.  According to Musk, these products could make Tesla the most valuable company in the world one day -- in fact, he thinks there is a possibility it could be worth more than the next five largest companies combined.

More than 60 protests were planned for Saturday, and a dozen more for Sunday, at Tesla showrooms across the United States, as backlash continues against CEO Elon Musk for his cost-cutting role at the Department of Government Efficiency.
Tesla shares were among the worst hit this week by tariffs.
Figuring out if cars are about to get more expensive is easy. They are. By just how much is harder to figure.

A 2014 "60 Minutes" interview with Elon Musk is suddenly back in rotation on X and it's not hard to see why. With headlines swirling about Musk backing away from his role at the Department of Government Efficiency and calls for federal spending cuts growing louder, the clip is a timely throwback to a different kind of Musk headline—one where he wasn't slashing budgets but writing checks to the government. In the resurfaced interview, journalist Scott Pelley zeroed in on Tesla's taxpayer-funded b

A shareholder is calling for Musk to take immediate action.

Wedbush Securities' Dan Ives, one of Wall Street's most vocal tech bulls, lowered his 12-month price target for Tesla's stock to $315 from $550.  Tesla shares are down 41% this year, closing at $239.43 on Friday.  Ives said in a Sunday note that Trump's tariffs are a "double-whammy" for Tesla, which sources much of its parts and batteries from abroad.
Rivian, Nio, and Polestar could thrive as Tesla tumbles.

Rising competition and the negative impact of Tesla CEO Elon Musk and his role with the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) appear to have been the main culprits.  Tesla's core business is making and selling electric vehicles, and this business seems to be feeling the heat.  As electric vehicle sales have seemingly been on the rise, Tesla has seen sales fall in Europe and China.
Wedbush Slashes Tesla, Apple Outlook Amid Mounting Trade Pressure

The main US stock measures were tracking in the red before Monday's opening bell, pointing to more t

Tesla and Apple will be among the top U.S. companies most badly damaged by President Trump's tariff campaign, Wedbush analysts said in a pair of research notes.  For Tesla, the resulting trade war is a double whammy, they noted.  China is also a key region for Tesla, and Trump's tariffs have created a backlash against Elon Musk there that will drive customers to BYD and other Chinese competitors, they added.
Bank earnings arriving as trade war intensifies, Tesla price target slashed amid Musk ‘brand crisis tornado,’ and more news to start your day.

Tesla  stock was tumbling in premarket trading Monday after longtime bull Wedbush analyst Dan Ives slashed his price target.  Shares of the electric vehicle maker were down 3% in premarket trading at $231.92, while  and  futures were dropping 2.1% and 2.6%, respectively.  Ives lowered his price target from a Street high (among major brokers) of $550 a share to $315 a share, down 43%.

Apple (AAPL) stock is on the decline after the Wedbush analyst also lowered his Apple price target to $250 from $325 due to the impact of tariffs. Wedbush analysts led by Tesla bull Dan Ives cut their price target for the electric vehicle maker's stock nearly in half.
Shares dropped 10.4% on Friday following a weak Q1 delivery report of 337,000 vehicles.

Shares of Tesla (NASDAQ: TSLA) traded close to 6% lower as of 10:31 a.m. ET today, but had traded as much as 10.5% down before broader market volatility set in, causing volatile swings in shares.  Longtime bull Dan Ives, an analyst at Wedbush, slashed his price target on the electric carmaker by 43%, while maintaining a buy rating.  Ives, who formerly had the highest price target on Wall Street, lowered his expectations on Tesla's stock from $550 per share to $315, which still implies significant upside from current levels, although shares of Tesla are off some 42% this year.
Tesla (TSLA) stock was falling yet again Monday, down more than 3% in morning trading as markets headed for another brutal day in the wake of President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs.

The "Magnificent Seven" stocks sank on Monday, extending a market rout that has wiped off around $2 trillion from their combined value as investors worry about the financial fallout of U.S. President Donald Trump's global tariff war.  The latest slide followed cuts in price target for Apple and Tesla shares from one of Wall Street's most bullish tech analysts, Dan Ives, who warned of a "tariff economic armageddon".  The cuts came as Trump doubled down on tariffs on Sunday, telling investors to endure the consequences and ruling out trade talks with China for now.
President Trump thus far has faced limited public critiques from Republican allies on his tariff plans. The president's top aides have not been so lucky.
It hasn't been pretty for the "Magnificent Seven."
Tesla stock is now down over 40% in 2025. Is it time to buy?

Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) is sitting on nearly 2,400 unsold Cybertrucks across the U.S., according to new data from Tesla-Info. That's about $200 million worth of inventory for a vehicle CEO Elon Musk once said had “over 1 million” reservations. But more than a year after deliveries began, the Cybertruck has become a tough sell. President Donald Trump’s new tariff policies aren’t just sending the markets crashing and people panicking; they’re creating infighting within his administration.

Investing.com -- Illustrating signs of cracks in the upper echelons of the Trump administration, Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO and DOGE chief Elon Musk continues to lash out publicly at key Trump advisor and tariff architect Peter Navarro, calling him a "moron."
Elon Musk has called one of Donald Trump’s top advisers “truly a moron” amid a deepening split in the White House over the tariff regime.
There might be trouble in paradise for President Donald Trump and Elon Musk, one of the president’s most visible and influential advisers.

There's some infighting among President Donald Trump's top advisers. Elon Musk called trade counselor Peter Navarro a "moron" and said he is "dumber than a sack of bricks" in a series of social media posts. Bloomberg's Ed Ludlow reports on what could be causing this riff.

Elon Musk continued his spat with Peter Navarro, President Trump’s top adviser on trade policy, saying in a social-media post that Navarro “is truly a moron.”  Musk’s retort came after Navarro said in a TV interview Monday that Musk—the chief executive of Tesla, one of the world’s largest makers of electric vehicles—is a “car assembler.”  Navarro also said that the component parts of Musk’s vehicles are made overseas.
Nvidia and its "Magnificent Seven" peers had shed $1.8 trillion in value last week

The trade-war selloff took a breather on Tuesday, buoying Big Tech firms including Nvidia (NVDA), Tesla (TSLA), Meta (META), and Microsoft (MSFT), after a mixed day on Monday and two especially gnarly days last week wiped $1.8 trillion off the market value of leading tech stocks.

Things are getting pretty testy between Elon Musk and Trump's top trade adviser Peter Navarro.  Musk, a senior adviser to Trump on slashing the federal government, called Navarro "truly a moron" and "dumber than a sack of bricks," in social media posts that responded to Navarro's televised comment that the Tesla CEO was merely a car "assembler," using auto parts from around the world, rather than a car manufacturer.  In the CNBC clip posted to X, Navarro said it was bad for U.S. economic security to have cars assembled in the U.S. using foreign parts.
Personal pleas, public fallout, and the company turned political pawn--can Tesla survive the trade war reboot?

Investors watching shares fluctuate widely on Tuesday might have missed a potentially important development in the Trump administration.  Tesla’s stock move mirrored the market as investors continued to struggle with President Donald Trump’s tariff policies.  Advisor Peter Navarro is a staunch defender of tariffs and one of the architects of Trump’s trade policy.
The global EV industry is shifting in a direction that doesn't favor Tesla.

China's electric vehicle market has rapidly transformed, asserting itself as a global leader in production, sales, and technological advancement. By early 2025, new energy vehicles, including battery electric and plug-in hybrid vehicles, make up nearly half of all passenger vehicle sales in the country. This growth is fueled by strong government policies, strategic subsidies, and investments in infrastructure, alongside ambitious electrification goals in major cities. Leading domestic...

Tesla (TSLA) stock has hit a roadblock in the past three years, and investors are growing wary of CEO Elon Musk and his impact on Tesla’s brand. Earlier this month, the American electric vehicle (EV) giant reported 336,681 cars delivered in Q1 2025, representing a 13% year-over-year decline from Q1 2024. The figure missed analyst expectations of 370,000 vehicles and prompted a JPMorgan analyst to reiterate an Underweight rating on Tesla and express concerns over “unprecedented brand damage.” As

(Bloomberg) -- Short sellers, or traders who wager on share price declines, are up $159 billion in paper profits over just six trading days after an escalating trade war sent the US stock market plummeting down more than 10%.
